cheatsheetvideos.quote: David Got help for his Class M using our Cheat sheet!
Jose explains how the motorcycle cheat sheet helped him pass his written exam.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.explanation: A five-sided yellow or yellow-green sign alerts drivers to either a school zone or school crossing.

questions.question: This red and white sign means you should:
questions.answerA: Stop and check for traffic coming from both directions before proceeding.
questions.answerB: Give the right-of-way to traffic on the road you wish to enter or cross.
questions.answerC: Maintain a steady speed and check for traffic coming from all directions.
questions.explanation: A three-sided yield sign indicates that you must slow down and be ready to stop, if necessary, to let any vehicle, bicyclist, or pedestrian pass before you proceed. In this case, you do not have the right-of-way.

questions.question: Your knees should be:
questions.explanation: Keep your knees against the gas tank to help with your balance as you turn the motorcycle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Lane ends or roadway narrows ahead.
questions.answerD: Freeway on-ramp ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign warns drivers that the right lane is ending or that the road is narrowing ahead.

questions.question: What should you be most concerned about when you see this sign?
questions.answerA: Driving with your headlights out of alignment because one side of your car is higher than the other.
questions.answerB: Damaging a tire from drifting onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Hydroplaning, if the shoulder has water on it.
questions.answerD: Losing control of the vehicle if you drift onto the shoulder.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the shoulder is lower than the road in the area ahead. If you drift off of the roadway and one wheel drops onto a low shoulder, do not slam on the brakes or steer sharply to try to get back onto the roadway. This could easily cause you to lose control of your vehicle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerD: Do not block intersection.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to potential traffic merging from the right. Drivers should prepare to allow the traffic to merge safely.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerD: Two-way left turn.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that drivers turning left at a green light must yield to oncoming traffic and may complete the turn when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers that:
questions.answerA: The right lane is ending and traffic should merge left.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers that the number of lanes is reduced ahead and that traffic should merge left.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerD: Keep left.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This warning sign indicates that drivers are about to encounter a divided highway.

questions.question: If you approach an uncontrolled intersection at the same time as another vehicle:
questions.answerA: The vehicle on the left should yield to the vehicle on the right.
questions.answerB: You should flash your headlight to signal that the other vehicle should proceed.
questions.answerC: You should continue through the intersection and expect the other vehicle to stop.
questions.explanation: If you approach an intersection that is not marked with signs or traffic lights at the same time as another driver, the driver on the left must yield to the driver on the right.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.explanation: A triangular red and white sign indicates that you must yield the right-of-way.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerC: All traffic must go straight ahead.
questions.answerD: A road joins from the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is an intersection ahead. A road joins from the right.

questions.question: Maintaining a space cushion between your motorcycle and its surroundings is important because it:
questions.answerB: Allows you time to react to unexpected situations.
questions.answerC: Keeps traffic flowing at a steady pace.
questions.answerD: Keeps other drivers alert.
questions.explanation: The only way to be sure you will have enough time to react to mistakes made by other drivers is to leave plenty of space between you and the vehicles around you.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerD: Lane ends.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that drivers should keep right to avoid an upcoming potential driving hazard.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Cars in the right lane must slow down.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates that there could be traffic merging from the right, so drivers should prepare to allow traffic to safely merge.

questions.question: You will ______ hear a tire going flat.
questions.answerD: Seldom
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists will seldom hear their tire go flat. Tire failure is more commonly indicated by a sudden change in handling.

questions.question: The faster you drink:
questions.answerA: The more the alcohol will accumulate in your body.
questions.answerB: The faster the alcohol is removed from your body.
questions.answerC: The more minimal the effects of the alcohol will be.
questions.answerD: The more likely you will be able to evade being pulled over.
questions.explanation: The faster you drink, the more alcohol will accumulate in your body. It is never safe to operate a motor vehicle after drinking alcohol in any amount.

questions.question: As weight transfers to the front of your bike while you are braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Gradually increase pressure to the front brake.
questions.answerC: Not worry. The weight transfer will not have an effect on your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Try to lock the front tire.
questions.explanation: While you are braking, gradually increase the amount of pressure applied to the front brake lever as the weight of the bike is transferred forward to the front tire.

questions.question: Riding gloves should:
questions.answerA: Not be worn because they will make your hands too hot.
questions.answerB: Be worn to provide a better grip on the handgrips.
questions.answerC: Not be worn because they will make it more difficult to work the controls.
questions.answerD: Be worn only on cooler days.
questions.explanation: Gloves made of leather, or another durable material, should be worn when riding. They will provide you with an improved grip on the handgrips, as well as help protect your hands in the event of a crash.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have little experience on their motorcycles.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes involve riders with little experience on their motorcycle.

questions.question: You are most likely to get into a collision:
questions.explanation: The greatest potential for conflict between you and other traffic exists at intersections.

questions.question: If you must stop quickly in a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Straighten up, square the handlebars, and stop.
questions.answerB: Abruptly apply both brakes while leaning.
questions.answerD: Apply only the front brake.
questions.explanation: If you must stop quickly while in a curve, you should first straighten and square the handlebars, then stop. If straightening your motorcycle is not possible, you should apply the brakes smoothly and gradually, reduce your lean angle, then increase the brake pressure as you slow down.

questions.question: Usually a good way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerB: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle tailgaters is usually to change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by prompting them to continue tailgating you at the higher speed.

questions.question: You have an improved chance of surviving a crash if you wear:
questions.explanation: You will get the most head and neck protection from a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. The single most effective thing you can do to improve your chances of surviving a crash is wear a properly secured, good-quality helmet.

questions.question: Since most crashes happen in daylight, you:
questions.answerA: Do not need to wear brightly-colored clothing during the day.
questions.answerB: Should wear brightly-colored clothing during the day.
questions.answerC: Should wear dark clothing during the day.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen in broad daylight. To make yourself more noticeable, wear brightly-colored clothing when riding, even during the daytime.

questions.question: When you are being passed by another vehicle, which part of the lane should you ride in?
questions.answerD: It doesn’t matter.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally safest to ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding on the side nearest the passing vehicle increases the risk of colliding with them. Riding on the side farthest from the passing vehicle is also dangerous, as it could tempt the driver to re-enter your lane before it is safe to do so.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should tell them to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle after the engine has been started.
questions.answerB: Sit as far forward as they can without crowding you.
questions.answerC: Hold firmly onto your waist, hips, or belt.
questions.answerD: Feel free to talk whenever they want.
questions.explanation: To help keep the operator focused on riding, passengers should avoid unnecessary conversation or movement. Passengers should get on a motorcycle only after the engine has been started. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator and hold firmly onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: To avoid confusing other drivers, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn off your turn signal after you complete a turn or lane change.
questions.answerC: Use your horn only in emergency situations.
questions.explanation: After completing a turn or lane change, deactivate your turn signal. Leaving your signal on after moving to the right or left can confuse other road users.

questions.question: When entering a curve, a group should:
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is usually best, a group should switch into a single-file formation when turning, taking curves, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: When riding with a heavy load, you will want to adjust the:
questions.answerD: Brake light.
questions.explanation: Before riding with a heavy load, you should make sure your tire pressure, spring pre-load, air shocks, and dampers are at the settings recommended for the relevant weight.

questions.question: When braking, you should use:
questions.answerD: Either brake, but never both at the same time.
questions.explanation: Always simultaneously use both brakes to stop. The brakes are most effective when used at the same time.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, you should look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: When turning, you should:
questions.answerA: Move your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerB: Turn just your head, not your shoulders, to look through the turn.
questions.answerC: Turn your head and shoulders to look through the turn.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn only your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon. Turning your shoulders may cause you to steer off course.

questions.question: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to make eye contact with other drivers.
questions.answerD: Ride in a weaving pattern.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, leave your headlight turned on and ride in a lane position that most easily allows oncoming traffic to see you. Maintain a space cushion that allows you to take evasive action if necessary. Never assume that another driver sees you, even if you make eye contact with the driver.

questions.question: It is a good idea to wear reflective clothing:
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Wearing reflective and brightly-colored clothing is always a good idea when riding a motorcycle. Crashes occur in broad daylight and at night, so it is best to wear highly visible clothing at any time of day.

questions.question: Reflective material on your helmet:
questions.answerC: Should only be used at night.
questions.answerD: Does not help you to be seen.
questions.explanation: Reflective material on a vest or on the sides of your helmet can make you more visible to other drivers and should be used both day and night.

questions.question: Which of the following will protect your eyes from the wind?
questions.answerD: Eyeglasses
questions.explanation: Goggles and face shields can protect a rider's eyes from the wind. Windshields, eyeglasses, and sunglasses generally do not shield a rider's eyes adequately enough.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked cars to your right when there is no oncoming traffic to your left, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay toward the right side of your lane.
questions.answerB: Stay toward the left side of your lane.
questions.answerD: Use your rearview mirrors more frequently than usual.
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked cars, it is generally best to stay on the side of your lane that is not directly next to the cars. This will help to protect you from potential hazards like car doors being opened or people stepping out from between the cars. If there is traffic coming from the opposite direction, it is a good idea to stay in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Allow you to blend in with traffic.
questions.answerC: Encourage others to use your lane.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: If the road is wet, you should avoid:
questions.answerA: The left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: All areas of the lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks collect in a strip in the center portion of a lane. This strip usually still provides enough traction for motorcyclists to operate safely, except when the road is wet. The strip is usually narrow enough that you can ride to its side and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You are about to enter a one-way street the wrong way.
questions.answerC: Do not drive in this lane.
questions.answerD: Traffic turning left on the green light must yield to oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: This sign is used with a traffic signal to tell drivers that left-turning traffic does not have the right-of-way and must instead wait for oncoming traffic to clear.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: When pavement is wet, reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: The road ahead winds a series of turns or curves.
questions.answerD: Steep grade ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that pavement is slippery when wet. In wet conditions, you should reduce your speed, avoid braking or changing direction suddenly, and increase the distance between your vehicle and the one ahead.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerD: Sharp left turn ahead.
questions.explanation: A regulatory sign displaying a red circle with a red slash through the middle indicates that a specific action is prohibited. U-turns are not permitted where this sign is posted.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a pedestrian crosswalk.

questions.question: An orange-colored sign like this means:
questions.explanation: Orange-colored signs indicate construction areas. Proceed with caution.

questions.question: When the lights on this sign are flashing, what should you do?
questions.answerA: Stop and wait until the train passes.
questions.answerC: Turn around and find an alternate route.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing that is controlled by a sign with flashing lights, you must come to a complete stop and wait until the train has passed and the lights have stopped flashing before proceeding. Never try to outdrive a train.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. Warning signs may alert drivers to areas where animals, people, and vehicles are likely to cross traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerD: Yield.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that parking is not permitted.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerC: Fines double in a work zone.
questions.answerD: Stop ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to potential bicycle cross traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerD: Apply your brakes quickly.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that the road is slippery when wet.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Slow down if an emergency vehicle is approaching.
questions.answerB: Look both ways as you cross the intersection.
questions.answerC: Always come to a full stop at the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.
questions.explanation: Decrease your speed as you approach an intersection with a yield sign. Prepare to stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians in the intersection or crossroad. You must come to a full stop at a yield sign if traffic conditions require it.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerD: Roadwork ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers to be cautious when driving under conditions that may cause the roadway to become wet and slippery.

questions.question: What are the colors of signs that tell you the distance to the next exit on a highway?
questions.answerD: Green with white letters
questions.explanation: Signs providing information about destinations are green with white letters or symbols.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Sharp turn to the right ahead.
questions.answerB: Upcoming sharp left and right turns.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns the driver that there is an upcoming winding road. Speed should be adjusted appropriately.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Right turn on red light permitted with caution.
questions.answerC: All traffic must turn right at next intersection.
questions.explanation: Signs with a red circle and diagonal line over a black symbol indicate the the action represented by the symbol is prohibited. In this case, the sign indicates that right turns are prohibited.

questions.question: When planning a long group ride, which of the following ideas should not be implemented?
questions.answerA: The lengths of travel segments should be based on the least experienced rider.
questions.answerB: Breaks should be minimized so the riders can get to their destination as soon as possible.
questions.answerC: Inexperienced riders should be placed behind the leaders.
questions.answerD: The group should maintain a staggered riding formation.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, the length of a route and the lengths of segments of travel should be based on the skill level of the least experienced rider. Groups of riders should take regular breaks to reduce fatigue. Inexperienced riders should be placed behind the leader so more experienced riders can keep an eye on them from behind. It is generally best to ride in a staggered formation.

questions.question: Hearing protection is:
questions.explanation: Long-term exposure to wind and engine noise can damage your hearing, even if you wear a helmet. It is a good idea to use hearing protection every time you ride to help prevent hearing damage.

questions.question: When looking through a turn, you should:
questions.answerC: Turn your head, shoulders, and torso.
questions.explanation: Look through every turn by turning just your head, not your shoulders, and keeping your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: Signals on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Serve little purpose since motorcycles are smaller than most other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are very important to alert other motorists to a rider's intentions.
questions.answerC: Should not be used if no vehicles are close to the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Are more complicated than those on a car.
questions.explanation: You are especially vulnerable as a motorcyclist, so it is very important to use your turn signals to alert others to your intentions. Always use them any time that you plan to change lanes or turn, even if you don't think anyone else is nearby.

questions.question: A difference between googles and a windshield is:
questions.answerA: Goggles will protect you from the wind, but a windshield won’t.
questions.answerB: A windshield will protect you from the wind, but goggles won't.
questions.answerC: A windshield will keep your eyes from watering better than goggles.
questions.explanation: Googles will protect your eyes from the wind, but most windshields will not. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for goggles or a face shield.

questions.question: A motorcyclist can discourage other vehicles from lane sharing by:
questions.answerA: Riding in the left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: Riding in the center portion of a lane.
questions.answerC: Giving dirty looks if another driver moves into their lane.
questions.answerD: Riding in a zigzag pattern to fill up a lane.
questions.explanation: Any time a driver may be tempted to try to squeeze into your lane next to you, ride in the center portion of the lane to discourage them from doing so.

questions.question: A good way to handle a tailgater is to:
questions.answerA: Encourage the tailgater to pass by slowing down or changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.explanation: If you can do so safely, change lanes and let the tailgater pass. Speeding up may only result in them continuing to tailgate you at a higher speed, increasing the danger.

questions.question: Which of the following is a good color to wear to be seen?
questions.answerD: Deep blue
questions.explanation: Orange, red, yellow, or green clothing can make you easier to see while riding a motorcycle. Wear brightly-colored clothing no matter what time of day you are riding.

questions.question: To minimize the potential for fatigue, you should:
questions.explanation: Taking frequent rest breaks during a long trip can help reduce fatigue. Stimulants, such as caffeine, can ultimately increase the danger of fatigue because you may become extremely tired when they begin to wear off. Wind, rain, snow, and other elements can also increase levels of fatigue, so dress warmly (as needed) and invest in a windshield, especially if you plan to ride long distances.

questions.question: One of the benefits of performing regular maintenance on your motorcycle is that:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle will ride well for a long period of time.
questions.answerB: The maintenance check will take a lot of time.
questions.answerD: Maintenance checks can often prevent parking tickets.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle will continue to ride like new if it is properly maintained and routine inspections become a part of its regular maintenance cycle.

questions.question: Which of the following is not important when looking for a motorcycle helmet?
questions.answerA: The helmet meets U.S. Department of Transportation standards.
questions.answerB: The helmet fits snugly all the way around your head.
questions.answerC: The helmet has no obvious defects, such as cracks or loose padding.
questions.answerD: The helmet looks cool.
questions.explanation: To ensure that a helmet will provide you with as much protection as possible, check to see if it meets U.S. DOT and state standards; fits snugly all the way around your head; and has no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Always scan the road ahead and anticipate potential risks.
questions.answerB: Focus on the controls, including the speedometer, rather than the road.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with hazards, because hazards are minimal on the roadway.
questions.answerD: Always look ahead, but try not to look for hazards.
questions.explanation: When riding, always look well ahead of your vehicle to help you anticipate potential hazards. Doing this will help you react to hazards before meeting them.

questions.question: If you accidentally lock your rear brake on a good traction surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Let go of the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Keep the rear brake locked until you stop.
questions.answerC: Release the rear brake and only use the front brake.
questions.explanation: If you accidentally lock the rear tire on a good traction surface, leave it locked until you can come to a complete stop. Even with a locked rear wheel, you will be able to control a motorcycle on a surface with good traction as long as the motorcycle is upright and traveling in a straight line.

questions.question: If your front wheel locks while you are braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the tire locked up, as it will help you stop more quickly.
questions.answerB: Release the front brake and only use the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Release the front brake immediately and re-apply it.
questions.explanation: If the front wheel locks up while you are braking, release the pressure from the front brake. Immediately re-apply pressure to the brake with controlled gradual pressure.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to weave while you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, you should:
questions.answerA: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the surface.
questions.answerB: Tighten your hold on the handle grips and increase your speed to get past the hazard.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder instead of on the grooves.
questions.explanation: The weaving motion that occurs when a motorcycle rides over rain grooves or bridge gratings is generally not dangerous. If you experience weaving when riding over one of these surfaces, simply relax and proceed straight across the grooves or gratings at a steady speed. Trying to compensate for the weaving motion by zigzagging is more dangerous than riding straight.

questions.question: When traveling on wet pavement, a motorcycle rider:
questions.answerA: Should travel in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Should follow in the wheel tracks of vehicles ahead.
questions.answerD: Should only use the front brake when stopping.
questions.explanation: Under wet conditions, it is recommended that you avoid the oily center strip of the lane and ride in the wheel tracks left by vehicles ahead.

questions.question: In hot weather, wearing a riding jacket:
questions.answerA: Can help protect against heat exhaustion and dehydration.
questions.answerB: Is discouraged because it can cause heat-related problems.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if the jacket is a light color.
questions.answerD: Is not important.
questions.explanation: A riding jacket and long pants should still be worn when riding in hot weather. In addition to their other safety benefits, they can protect a rider from heat exhaustion and dehydration.

questions.question: When riding behind a car, traveling in the left third of the lane allows the driver to see you in their side mirror. What is a downside to this?
questions.answerA: Most people don’t use their side mirrors as often as they use their rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: The wind may prevent the use of a side mirror.
questions.answerC: Side mirrors should not be used by motorists.
questions.explanation: Most drivers do not look at their side mirrors as often as they look at their rearview mirror. Therefore, when following a car, it is generally most advantageous to ride in the center portion of the lane where you are most likely to be visible in the driver's rearview mirror.

questions.question: When a tire goes flat, the rider can often hear it.
questions.explanation: You will seldom actually hear a tire go flat. Instead, tire failure may be indicated by a sudden change in the motorcycle's handling.

questions.question: Keep an expanded cushion of space between your motorcycle and the vehicle in front of you:
questions.answerA: When conditions will make stopping more difficult than usual.
questions.answerB: When you want to look at the scenery.
questions.answerC: To encourage other drivers to cut you off.
questions.answerD: To prevent the driver in front of you from knowing you are there.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a larger following distance.

questions.question: A rider's boots or shoes should:
questions.answerC: Be made of a soft, pliable material.
questions.explanation: For riding, choose footwear that is sturdy and high enough to cover and support your ankles. Soles should be made of hard, durable, slip-resistant material.

questions.question: If a sign prohibits the use of a moped on a freeway:
questions.answerA: Mopeds cannot be used on the freeway.
questions.answerB: Mopeds can only be used on the freeway when traffic is moving smoothly.
questions.answerC: Mopeds can be used on the freeway if they are not operated at speeds faster than 25 mph.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to operate a motor-driven cycle or moped on a freeway or expressway if signs are posted prohibiting their operation.

questions.question: When sitting on a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your arms to hold up your body.
questions.answerB: Sit at an angle so your arms can support your weight.
questions.answerC: Sit so you can use your arms to control the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Sit with a posture that allows you to use your arms to control your motorcycle. You should not be positioned in a way that requires your arms to prop up your body and support your weight.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should be:
questions.explanation: In a group, less experienced riders should be positioned toward the front, just behind the leader. This will allow more experienced riders to watch them from behind.

questions.question: As you slow or stop, you should:
questions.answerC: Take the bike out of gear.
questions.answerD: Stay in the same gear.
questions.explanation: You should shift down through the gears with the clutch as you slow or stop. Stay in first gear while you are stopped so you can move quickly, if needed.

questions.question: What message will be found on a red octagon-shaped sign?
questions.explanation: An octagonal (eight-sided) sign always means "stop." You must always come to a complete stop at this sign.

questions.question: When riding at night, a motorcyclist should:
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Riding at night can be dangerous because a rider’s ability to see and be seen by fellow motor vehicle operators is limited. It is recommended that riders adjust their riding behavior to compensate for this limited visibility by reducing their speed, maximizing their headlight usage, and increasing their following distance.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you may need to adjust:
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to add a few pounds of pressure to your tires if you plan to carry a passenger. Also, adjust the suspension to handle the additional weight.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to the right lane ending and tells them to prepare for potential merging traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerD: Two-way traffic.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow and black. This sign tells drivers that a lane is ending and that they should prepare to allow traffic to merge safely.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: The highway ahead curves only to the right.
questions.answerB: The highway ahead turns sharply to the right.
questions.answerC: The highway ahead curves to the right and then to the left.
questions.answerD: The highway ahead curves to the left and then to the right.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazardous conditions and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that the road ahead curves to the right and then to the left.

questions.question: When you see this sign, it means:
questions.answerA: There is an object on the roadway.
questions.answerB: Traffic is coming from the right.
questions.answerC: The road is curving sharply to the left.
questions.answerD: There is a merge point ahead.
questions.explanation: Chevron signs like this indicate that the road curves sharply in the direction indicated by the chevron (in this case, to the left). There may be several chevron signs placed throughout a curve.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.explanation: An eight-sided red sign means "stop."

questions.question: If you began a curve on the outside and no traffic is present when you are exiting the curve, you should move:
questions.answerA: Toward the center of the curve.
questions.answerB: Toward the inside of the curve.
questions.answerC: Toward the outside of the curve.
questions.explanation: If no traffic is present when you are taking a curve, start on the outside of the curve to increase your line of sight and the effective radius of the turn. As you turn, move toward the inside of the curve. As you pass the center of the curve and prepare to exit, move back toward the outside position. Remain aware of changing road and traffic conditions and adjust as necessary.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerD: Highway curves ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is merging traffic entering from the right.

questions.question: When slowing down or stopping, you must:
questions.explanation: Shift down through the gears as you slow down or stop. Stay in first gear while you are stopped to ensure that you can move quickly if you need to.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerC: You must come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: An octagonal sign always means stop. When approaching a stop sign, you must come to a complete stop at the marked stop line and proceed only when it is safe to do so. If there is no stop line, stop before the crosswalk. If there is no crosswalk, stop before the intersection at a point from which you can see oncoming traffic.

questions.question: To safely cross railroad tracks that run parallel to your lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Approach the tracks at a 90-degree angle.
questions.answerB: Approach the tracks at a 45-degree angle.
questions.explanation: To safely cross railroad tracks, trolley tracks, or pavement seams running parallel to your lane, move to a lane position that will allow you to cross them at an angle of at least 45 degrees. Then, make a quick, sharp turn. If you try to edge across, the tracks or seam could catch your tires and throw you off balance.

questions.question: On the freeway, you see a "Merging traffic“ sign. You should:
questions.answerB: Always remain at your present speed.
questions.answerC: Speed up to avoid congesting traffic.
questions.answerD: Move to another lane, if safe, to let traffic enter.
questions.explanation: When on a roadway with two or more lanes, you should make room for entering vehicles. If there is no one driving next to you, move over one lane.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerD: No right turn.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that right turns are prohibited.

questions.question: When it starts to rain, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Pull onto the shoulder and wait for it to stop raining.
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Roads become slippery when it first starts raining, especially in the center strip of a lane. When rain starts, it is generally safest to ride in the tire tracks left by other vehicles. The left tire track is often best.

questions.question: A motorcycle operator can slow down by:
questions.answerD: Rolling on the throttle.
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists often slow down by simply downshifting. Motorcyclists should be aware that slowing down in this manner does not activate the brake lights.

questions.question: A passenger on a motorcycle should:
questions.answerA: Put their feet on the ground when the motorcycle is stopped.
questions.answerB: Not ride without a back rest.
questions.answerC: Sit as far forward as possible without crowding the operator.
questions.explanation: A passenger on a motorcycle should sit as far forward as possible without crowding the operator. The passenger should keep both feet on the footrests at all times, even when stopped.

questions.question: Low-speed crashes:
questions.answerD: Happen frequently, so there is no need to worry about them.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes occur at speeds lower than 30 miles per hour. Even low-speed crashes can be fatal.

questions.question: The normal recommended following distance should be extended if:
questions.answerC: You believe stopping will be routine.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up your following distance.

questions.question: Since most crashes happen during daylight hours, you should:
questions.answerB: Wear bright clothing all the time.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder and stay out of traffic.
questions.answerD: Wear dark clothing all the time.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen in broad daylight. You should always wear brightly-colored clothing when riding to maximize your chances of being seen, even during the day.

questions.question: When braking where traction is reduced, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes more quickly than usual.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes more gently than usual.
questions.answerD: Not use the front brake.
questions.explanation: When slowing or stopping on a surface with reduced traction, you should use caution and apply the brakes more gently than usual.

questions.question: Should you wear gloves while riding a motorcycle?
questions.answerA: Yes. Your hands may cold while riding.
questions.answerB: Yes. They provide an improved grip and help protect your hands.
questions.answerC: No. Gloves are not recommended as they can interfere with the controls.
questions.explanation: Wearing gloves while riding provides an improved grip and help protect your hands. You should use gloves that are full-fingered and made of a durable material.

questions.question: Who should set the pace in a group of riders?
questions.answerB: The riders just behind the leader
questions.answerD: The oldest rider
questions.explanation: The last rider in a group of motorcyclists should set the pace of travel. Having the last rider set the pace will ensure that no riders are left behind.

questions.question: For the best protection, riding gloves should be made of:
questions.answerD: Silk.
questions.explanation: Gloves should be made of leather or another durable material to provide proper protection for the wearer.

questions.question: If someone is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder of the road.
questions.answerD: Allow them to pass.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to let them get in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let the tailgater pass. Riding faster may only increase the danger by prompting them to continue tailgating you at the higher speed.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger, a motorcycle responds to directional changes:
questions.explanation: A passenger places extra weight on a motorcycle. Because of the added weight, the motorcycle will respond to the operator's movements more slowly than it would otherwise, taking more time to speed up, slow down, and turn.

questions.question: In a slow, tight turn, the rider should:
questions.answerA: Counterbalance the leaning motorcycle by keeping their body upright.
questions.answerB: Lean at the same angle as the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Lean in the opposite direction of the motorcycle and the turn.
questions.answerD: Counterbalance their leaning body by keeping the motorcycle upright.
questions.explanation: When taking normal turns, lean at the same angle as your motorcycle. However, in slow, tight turns, you should counterbalance the leaning motorcycle by keeping your body upright.

questions.question: When riding over scored pavement in a work zone, you should:
questions.answerA: Look downward to see the changes in the road surface.
questions.answerB: Keep your head and eyes up.
questions.answerC: Stay to the left side of the lane.
questions.explanation: When riding over scored pavement in a work zone, keep your head and eyes up. Ride slowly, keep a steady throttle, and don't try to fight the handlebars.

questions.question: Reflective, brightly-colored helmets and clothing:
questions.answerA: Should only be worn when riding at night.
questions.answerB: Can help motorcycle riders be more visible.
questions.answerC: Do not increase a motorcycle rider's safety.
questions.explanation: Wearing brightly-colored or reflective clothing can increase your chances of being seen by other road users.

questions.question: To swerve correctly:
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.explanation: To execute a swerve, press the handgrip on the side of your desired turn. Press on the opposite handgrip to return to your original direction after you are clear of the hazard.

questions.question: You should do all of the following to lesson your chances of being in a crash, except:
questions.answerA: Be visible by wearing proper clothing and using your headlight.
questions.answerB: Communicate your intentions by using your turn signals and brake light.
questions.answerC: Search for hazards in your path.
questions.answerD: Hope the other drivers see you.
questions.explanation: To minimize your risk of a crash, ensure that you are visible to other drivers, communicating your intentions to other drivers, and maintaining a cushion of space around you. You should search for, identify, and separate hazards. Be prepared to react to anything that happens.

questions.question: You have an improved chance of avoiding serious injury in a crash if you wear all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: Wearing a U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT)-compliant helmet can help protect you against head and neck injuries in the event of a crash. A jacket made of leather or sturdy synthetic material can also protect you against injuries.

questions.question: Where is the throttle usually located?
questions.answerD: On the right handle grip
questions.explanation: The throttle of a motorcycle is usually located on the right handle grip. Be sure to know where all of your motorcycle's controls are located before riding.

questions.question: If taking a long trip, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to minimize the number of rest breaks.
questions.answerB: Use artificial stimulants, like caffeine, if you feel drowsy.
questions.answerC: Dress warmly to avoid getting too cold during the ride.
questions.answerD: Schedule more than 12 hours of riding a day.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of fatigue on a long trip, dress to protect yourself from tiring elements, such as wind, cold, and rain. Limit yourself to no more than six hours of riding per day and take rest brakes at least every two hours. Avoid using artificial stimulants, as these only result in extreme fatigue when they wear off.

questions.question: When being passed, do not move into the portion of the lane farthest from the passing vehicle because:
questions.answerA: The passing vehicle may re-enter your lane too early.
questions.answerB: You may prevent another vehicle from passing you.
questions.answerC: The portion of the lane nearest the passing vehicle is better.
questions.answerD: You are more likely to experience a wind blast from the passing vehicle on the far side of the lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed, you should not ride on the side of your lane that is farthest from the passing vehicle. Doing so may tempt the driver to return to your lane before there is actually room for them to do so safely.

questions.question: For motorcycle operators, helmets are:
questions.explanation: In Georgia, you are required to wear a U.S. Department of Transportation-compliant helmet any time you operate a motorcycle.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerB: Keep your intentions unknown from other drivers.
questions.answerC: Always stay within a foot of another vehicle.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: Passengers should:
questions.answerA: Hold onto the rider's hips, waist, or belt.
questions.explanation: Before beginning your ride, tell your passenger to maintain a firm grasp on your hips, waist, or belt. If there are secure handholds for your passenger, they may also hold those.

questions.question: Eye protection, such as goggles or a face shield, is:
questions.explanation: Eye protection is required to be used by riders of all ages. Eye protection may be used in the form of goggles, a face shield, glasses, or an approved windshield.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Parking spaces are reserved for people with disabled parking permits.
questions.answerC: Traffic in the lane must turn in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerD: Lanes are reserved for buses and vehicles with a driver and one or more passengers.
questions.explanation: This sign marks parking spaces that are reserved for people with disabled parking permits.

questions.question: What should you do when you see this sign?
questions.answerA: Look for a train station ahead.
questions.answerC: Slow down and yield for trains.
questions.answerD: Stop.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a railroad crossing on the road ahead. You should always slow down when approaching a railroad crossing. Trains cannot yield to cars, so you must let them pass before crossing the tracks.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerD: Intersection ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of two-way traffic ahead.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Lane reduction. The right lane ends soon and traffic should merge left.
questions.explanation: A warning sign is usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns that the number of lanes ahead is reduced and that traffic will need to merge to the left.

questions.question: An engine will seize due to:
questions.explanation: Engines seize when they are low on oil. Without oil, the engine’s moving parts cannot move smoothly against each other and the engine overheats.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.explanation: This sign means drivers cannot make a left turn. It is unsafe and unlawful to make a left turn at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: At a school crossing sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stop, whether there’s a stop sign or not.
questions.answerB: Watch for children and be ready to stop.
questions.answerC: Always sound your horn when you see children.
questions.answerD: Be ready to help children crossing the street.
questions.explanation: You must always yield to pedestrians who are in or about to enter a crosswalk. Be alert to pedestrians when driving across intersections or turning.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerD: Do not block intersection.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that there is an upcoming stop sign and that they should prepare to come to a complete stop before proceeding.

questions.question: The first thing you should do if your throttle becomes stuck is:
questions.answerC: Twist the throttle back and forth.
questions.explanation: If your throttle becomes stuck, try twisting it back and forth several times. If this does not free your throttle, immediately operate the engine cut-off switch and pull in the clutch at the same time.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that turns in the direction of the arrow (in this case, to the right) are prohibited.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerD: No parking.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. Wherever this regulation sign is posted, U-turns are not permitted.

questions.question: Which of the following surfaces is unlikely to provide poor traction for motorcyclists?
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you must:
questions.answerA: Stop completely and check for pedestrians and cross traffic.
questions.answerB: Slow down without coming to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Stop completely and wait for a green light.
questions.answerD: Slow down and check for traffic.
questions.explanation: Any eight-sided sign is a stop sign. At an intersection with a stop sign, you must stop completely and check for pedestrians and cross traffic in the intersection. Wait for the intersection to clear before proceeding.

questions.question: Riding a motorcycle is ______ driving a car.
questions.answerD: No different from
questions.explanation: Riding a motorcycle is more tiring than driving a car, especially on a long trip. Avoid riding when you are tired. Fatigue can affect your control of the motorcycle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: There is a 35 mph speed zone after the curve ahead.
questions.answerB: Drive no slower than 35 mph around the upcoming curve.
questions.answerC: Approach the upcoming curve at a speed of 35 mph or slower.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. These signs may be accompanied by speed advisory plaques that indicate the speed with which you should proceed.

questions.question: On which of the following surfaces does a motorcycle have the best traction?
questions.answerD: Leaves
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: If another driver is following you too closely, it is best to:
questions.answerB: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerD: Get off the roadway.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Increasing your speed may only encourage the driver to tailgate you at a higher speed.

questions.question: When choosing a helmet, you will get the most protection by using a helmet that:
questions.answerD: Provides hearing protection.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you are getting as much protection as possible, choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. Helmets should fit snugly all the way around.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid danger, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the front brake while swerving.
questions.answerB: Brake and swerve at the same time.
questions.answerC: Either brake then swerve or swerve then brake.
questions.explanation: If a hazard requires you to brake and swerve, you should take these actions separately. Never brake while swerving because doing so can cause your motorcycle to fall over.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerC: At the tail end of the group.
questions.answerD: Beside the leader.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, riders with less experience should be positioned toward the front of the group, just behind the leader. This will allow more experienced riders to keep an eye on them without forcing the inexperienced rider to lead the group.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of an accident, you should:
questions.answerB: Follow the vehicle in front of you as closely as possible.
questions.answerC: Not look ahead and focus only on your controls.
questions.answerD: Communicate your intentions to other drivers.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: When braking on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerD: Not use any brakes, but downshift.
questions.explanation: To ride safely on a slippery surface, you should reduce your speed and avoid making sudden moves. Use both brakes if you must slow down or stop.

questions.question: Small vehicles can appear ______ and seem to be traveling ______ than they actually are.
questions.answerD: Closer, faster
questions.explanation: Small vehicles, like motorcycles, can visually seem to be farther away and moving more slowly than they actually are. This phenomenon can make it difficult for others on the road to accurately judge the location and speed of a smaller vehicle.

questions.question: What may help if you experience slippage of your drive chain?
questions.answerD: Applying the rear brake
questions.explanation: If you experience chain slippage, tightening the chain may help. If tightening the chain does not reverse the problem, replace the chain before continuing to ride your motorcycle.

questions.question: If the throttle is stuck, you should:
questions.answerC: Twist the throttle back and forth several times.
questions.answerD: Not try to twist the throttle.
questions.explanation: If your throttle becomes stuck, try twisting it back and forth several times. If this does not free your throttle, immediately operate the engine cut-off switch and pull in the clutch at the same time.

questions.question: A helmet should not:
questions.answerD: Have been previously worn in an accident.
questions.explanation: You will get the greatest amount of protection from a helmet if it meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards, fits snugly all the way around, and has no obvious defects. A helmet worn at the time of a crash should be replaced.

questions.question: You should use a larger cushion of space:
questions.answerC: When it is colder than usual.
questions.answerD: When you are following other motorcycles.
questions.explanation: A two-second following distance is generally appropriate. Allow a larger cushion of space when riding under conditions that will increase your stopping distance, such as when the road surface is icy or wet.

questions.question: As your motorcycle increases speed, you will:
questions.answerA: Need to shift up through the gears.
questions.answerB: Need to shift down through the gears.
questions.answerC: Need to put the motorcycle into neutral.
questions.explanation: It is necessary to shift into higher gears as your motorcycle increases its speed.

questions.question: A motorcycle operator can improve their visibility by:
questions.answerD: Wearing brightly-colored clothing.
questions.explanation: To maximize your chances of being seen by other road users, you should wear brightly-colored clothing with reflective materials, use your headlight at all times, and use your signals and brake light properly.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection usually takes:
questions.answerA: A few minutes and should be done no more than once a month.
questions.answerB: A few minutes and should be done before every ride.
questions.answerC: Over an hour and should be performed by a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Over an hour and must only be done if you will be carrying a passenger.
questions.explanation: Conduct a thorough pre-ride inspection before every ride. It should usually take only a few minutes.

questions.question: In general, which position within a lane is the best to ride in?
questions.answerC: There is no single best lane position.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. A responsible rider adjusts their position as conditions change.

questions.question: How can you regain control if your rear tire locks up?
questions.answerC: Swerve the bike in the direction with the fewest hazards.
questions.answerD: With the brake engaged, try to accelerate.
questions.explanation: To regain control of a locked rear wheel, the brake must be released. However, if you accidentally lock the rear brake on a good traction surface, you can keep it locked until you have completely stopped.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not a reason to keep a cushion of space between your motorcycle and the vehicle in front of you?
questions.answerA: It allows you more time to respond to hazards.
questions.answerB: It prevents you from finding an escape route.
questions.answerC: It provides space to maneuver your motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Maintaining an adequate space cushion ensures that you will have time to respond if another driver makes a mistake. A cushion of space also allows you the space you need to safely maneuver your motorcycle.

questions.question: To lessen the chances of a crash occurring, you should:
questions.explanation: To lessen the chances of a crash occurring, you should make yourself visible, communicate your intentions to others, maintain adequate space cushions, search your path of travel at least 12 seconds ahead, identify and separate hazards, and be prepared to react to changing conditions.

questions.question: When traveling in a group, riders should:
questions.answerA: Spread out to make the group easier to see.
questions.answerB: Stay close together to make the group easier to see.
questions.answerD: Ride in pairs.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, riders should maintain close ranks while also allowing adequate space cushions around each rider. Staying close together makes the group easier to see and reduces the risk that riders will become separated. Riders should not pair up because doing so does not allow adequate room for them to maneuver.

questions.question: A sign that your rear tire has suddenly gone flat is that:
questions.answerA: The back of your motorcycle is swaying from side to side.
questions.answerC: A discharge of air can be seen.
questions.explanation: If the rear tire of a motorcycle goes flat, the back of the motorcycle may jerk or sway from side to side. If you experience this movement when riding your motorcycle, you should stop riding and check your tires as soon as possible.

questions.question: If your front tire goes flat while you are riding:
questions.answerC: There will be no change in the steering.
questions.answerD: The ride will feel too smooth.
questions.explanation: If the front tire of a motorcycle fails, it will cause the steering to feel heavy. If your steering feels heavy, immediately exit the road and inspect your tires.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should be placed:
questions.answerA: In the front of the group.
questions.answerC: At the back of the group.
questions.answerD: Anywhere within the group.
questions.explanation: Inexperienced riders should ride near the front of a group, just behind the leader, so more experienced riders can keep an eye on them from behind.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerA: First apply the front brake, then the rear.
questions.answerB: First apply the rear brake, then the front.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.answerD: Use brakes in any order.
questions.explanation: Both brakes should be used at the same time whenever you slow or stop.

questions.question: When approaching a blind intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the portion of the lane that will bring you into other drivers' fields of vision at the earliest possible moment.
questions.answerB: Always be in the left lane to be the farthest from oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Slowly sneak up to the intersection.
questions.answerD: Weave slightly in your lane so your headlight has a better chance of being spotted.
questions.explanation: When approaching a blind intersection, move into the part of the lane that will bring you into an oncoming driver's field of vision at the earliest possible moment. For example, when approaching a blind corner to your right, you may be seen sooner if you are in the left portion of your lane and not in the center portion.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerD: A divided highway begins.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead becomes a divided highway. Keep to the right of the divider or median.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign tells drivers to prepare to allow traffic to safely merge from the right.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns that the divided highway ends ahead. Prepare to change lanes or shift lane position.

questions.question: A person who is above the legal drinking age with a minimum prohibited alcohol concentration (PAC) of _____ is considered legally intoxicated.
questions.answerD: 0.15 percent
questions.explanation: Riding with a minimum prohibited alcohol concentration (PAC) of 0.08 percent is considered riding while legally intoxicated. It is illegal and dangerous to ride a motorcycle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: When passing parked vehicles, motorcycle riders should be especially cautious of:
questions.answerB: Motorists looking for a place to park.
questions.explanation: When passing parked vehicles, use caution. You may encounter vehicles pulling away from the curb or leaving parking spaces.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.explanation: This sign is displayed on slow-moving vehicles.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerC: Last turn before a toll road.
questions.explanation: Orange is the standard color for work zone activity. If you see orange signs, cones, or barrels while driving, stay alert and be prepared for unexpected driving conditions. This sign alerts drivers to an upcoming flagger whose directions should be obeyed by all drivers.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerD: Bumps in the road.
questions.explanation: This sign warns drivers that the divided highway ends ahead.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates the presence of a crosswalk, regardless of if it is marked on the pavement or not. Upon seeing this sign, you should be alert and allow any pedestrians to cross the road safely.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Cars in right lane must slow down.
questions.answerD: Pass only in the right lane.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates a merge ahead. It warns that two lanes of traffic moving in the same direction are about to become one.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.explanation: A triangular yellow sign with black lettering indicates a no passing zone. It will appear on the left side of a two-way, two-lane roadway at the beginning of an area where prohibitive pavement markings are also used.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The left lane is reserved for vehicles with a specific number of occupants.
questions.answerB: Specific turning movements are allowed from specific lanes.
questions.answerD: Drivers in both lanes are responsible for merging smoothly.
questions.explanation: This sign marks a high occupancy vehicle (HOV) lane. HOV lanes are reserved for use by buses and vehicles with a driver and one or more passengers, as indicated on the sign.

questions.question: This sign means you are approaching a railroad crossing that does not have a signal. You should:
questions.answerB: Proceed at a consistent speed while looking and listening for approaching trains.
questions.answerC: Slow down, look both ways, listen for any trains, and be prepared to stop if any trains are nearby.
questions.explanation: At a railroad crossing marked with this sign, a driver should look both ways, listen for any trains, and be prepared to stop if any trains are nearby. Never try to outdrive an oncoming train.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerD: No passing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead. The road splits into two one-way roadways separated by a median or divider. You must keep to the right.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Use the headlights of vehicles ahead to help you see.
questions.answerD: Ride only in the left portion of your lane.
questions.explanation: When riding at night, use your high beam (unless you are following or meeting another car), take advantage of the headlights of other vehicles, and wear reflective materials to increase your visibility. You should always be flexible about your lane position, selecting whichever position will help you to see, be seen, and have an adequate space cushion.

questions.question: When riding during the day, you should:
questions.answerA: Wear dark clothes since it is light outside.
questions.answerB: Wear bright clothes so other motorists can see you better.
questions.answerC: Be comfortable, wearing shorts if it is hot.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes occur in broad daylight. To make yourself more visible to other drivers, you should always wear brightly-colored clothing when riding, even during the day.

questions.question: Which formation is best for a group of riders entering a curve?
questions.answerD: Compressed
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is generally the best way for a group to maintain close ranks while also allowing each rider to maintain an adequate cushion of space. A single-file formation is preferable when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: The best source of information for your motorcycle is:
questions.answerC: Someone who has a different type of motorcycle.
questions.answerD: A television show about motorcycle riding.
questions.explanation: To be sure you are familiar with the specific type of motorcycle that you are planning to ride, read the owner's manual before riding it for the first time. This is particularly important if you are riding a borrowed motorcycle.

questions.question: You will get the most protection from a helmet if it is all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: A helmet will provide a rider with the best protection if it meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) standards; fits snugly all the way around; and has no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: Where is the engine cut-off switch usually located?
questions.answerD: Near the right footrest
questions.explanation: The engine cut-off switch is generally located next to the right handgrip. It is important to know where all of your motorcycle's controls are located before starting out.

questions.question: When loading cargo onto a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Pack heavier items in front of the tank bag.
questions.answerB: Pack lighter items near the front.
questions.answerC: Try to not place items over the rear axle.
questions.answerD: Place items behind the rear axle.
questions.explanation: Heavier items should be loaded in front of the tank bag. You should try to place the load over or in front of the rear axle. Putting the load behind the rear axle may affect your control.

questions.question: Increase your following distance if:
questions.answerD: You can see through the vehicle in front of you.
questions.explanation: Open up your following distance if your motorcycle will require a longer distance than normal to stop. Additionally, if you are riding in heavy traffic or if you cannot see through the vehicle in front of you, you should also increase your following distance.

questions.question: When riding behind a car, traveling in the center portion of the lane:
questions.answerA: Allows you to be seen in its rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Usually makes it difficult for the driver to see you.
questions.explanation: When following a car, you should ride in a position that allows the driver to see you in their rearview mirror. Usually, that means riding in the center portion of the lane. Because most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than they check their side mirrors, being in this lane position increases the chance that they will see you.

questions.question: When stopping, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Grab at the front brake lever.
questions.answerB: Keep your knees against the gas tank and keep your eyes up.
questions.answerC: Apply increasing pressure to the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Only use the front brake.
questions.explanation: For maximum straight-line braking, you should apply the brakes smoothly and firmly. As more weight transfers forward, more will be more traction available at the front wheel, allowing you to apply the front brake with progressively increasing force while reducing the pressure being used on the rear brake. Keep your knees against the gas tank and your eyes up to help keep yourself moving in a straight line.

questions.question: The faster you drink alcohol:
questions.answerA: The faster the alcohol is removed from your body.
questions.answerB: The faster the alcohol accumulates in your body.
questions.answerC: The less the alcohol affects your body.
questions.explanation: The faster you drink, the faster the alcohol will accumulate in your body. Alcohol leaves a person's system at an average of one drink per hour. If you consume more than one drink in an hour, you will still have alcohol in your body after one hour has passed.

questions.question: Before a ride, a motorcycle operator should check the throttle. The throttle should:
questions.explanation: Check your clutch and throttle before riding your motorcycle. The throttle should snap back when you let go and the clutch should feel tight and smooth.

questions.question: You should operate the engine cut-off switch and pull in the clutch when:
questions.answerA: The throttle is stuck and you cannot free it.
questions.answerB: You start to lose control in a curve.
questions.explanation: If the throttle becomes stuck and you are unable to free it, immediately operate the engine cut-off switch and pull in the clutch at the same time. This will remove power from the rear wheel until you are able to safely leave the road and stop.

questions.question: An ideal lane position should:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerB: Place you in other drivers’ blind spots.
questions.answerC: Invite others to share your lane.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: If a rider in a group wants to ride faster than the others, what should the group do?
questions.answerA: Let the rider go ahead and meet up at a designated spot later.
questions.answerB: Speed up to accommodate the one rider.
questions.answerC: Split up and have every rider travel as fast or as slow as they want.
questions.answerD: Let the rider that wants to go faster lead the group.
questions.explanation: If one member of a group wants to ride faster than the others, it is best to let them go ahead of the group and meet at a designated spot later.

questions.question: A simple way to make your motorcycle easier to see is to:
questions.answerA: Ride with a large flag attached to its frame.
questions.answerB: Ride with the headlight turned on.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder whenever possible.
questions.explanation: You can make yourself easier to see by wearing brightly-colored, reflective clothing. Ride with your headlight on at all times and use your turn signals and brake light appropriately.

questions.question: When riding with a group of motorcyclists, a staggered formation:
questions.answerB: Should not be used when entering or exiting a highway.
questions.answerC: Should be used when riding in curves.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is generally advisable, a group of motorcyclists should switch to a single-file formation when riding in curves, turning, and entering or leaving a highway.

questions.question: Smoothly downshifting on motorcycles:
questions.answerB: Can allow the rider to engine brake.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if other vehicles are around.
questions.explanation: Engine braking by smoothly downshifting can be a useful option for motorcyclists. If you choose to engine brake, apply your brake lights separately to let other drivers know that you are slowing down.

questions.question: If you cannot avoid a slippery road, you should:
questions.answerA: Lean into the slippery section to maintain your balance.
questions.answerB: Maintain your speed to improve traction.
questions.answerC: Not worry about the road conditions.
questions.answerD: Keep your motorcycle upright and proceed as slowly as needed.
questions.explanation: It is best to entirely avoid slippery stretches of road. However, if there is no way to avoid such an area, keep your motorcycle upright and proceed as slowly as possible.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, which portion of the lane should you ride in?
questions.answerD: The shoulder
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, you should ride in the left portion of the lane to increase your line of sight and make yourself more visible to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Usually, a good way to handle a tailgater is to:
questions.answerA: Move onto the shoulder to get out of their way.
questions.answerB: Speed up and put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerD: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.explanation: Usually, the best way to handle a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to follow you at a faster speed.

questions.question: Where is the greatest potential for conflict between motorcycle operators and other drivers?
questions.answerD: In parking lots
